document.title: Whalen v. Ford Motor Credit Co.
document.full_title: CORNELIUS M. WHALEN, T/A TOWSON ASSOCIATES LIMITED PARTNERSHIP, TO ITS OWN USE AND TO THE USE OF ROBERT WHALEN COMPANY, INC. v. FORD MOTOR CREDIT COMPANY, A BODY CORPORATE
document.body: Before BUTZNER, MURNAGHAN, and SPROUSE, Circuit Judges. BUTZNER, Circuit Judge: In this diversity case, Ford Motor Credit Co. appeals from a judgment awarding $4,294,746 to Towson Associates, developer of a condominium, for breach of a financing commitment. Finding no cause for reversal in Ford's assignments of error, we affirm. I Ford asserts that the death of the judge who was trying the case required a mistrial. It contends that reassignment to another judge who proceeded with the trial contravenes the seventh amendment. The case was initially assigned to Judge C. Stanley Blair, who ruled on a number of pre-trial motions, empanelled the jury, and presided over the first three weeks of trial. After his death, Ford moved for a mistrial. Judge Murray, to whom the case had been reassigned, denied the motion, setting forth his reasons in a carefully considered opinion. Working diligently, Judge Murray was able to review, before the case was submitted to the jury, the entire pre-trial record and the transcript of the proceedings over which Judge Blair had presided in the three weeks before his death. Judge Murray appears to have become as well informed as Judge Blair about the early weeks of trial with the single exception that Judge Murray did not see the witnesses testify. This difference is immaterial, for it was the function of the jury, not the trial judge, to assess the credibility of the witnesses. There is no indication in the record that Judge Murray was unfamiliar with the case when he made various rulings and when he charged the jury. In its brief, Ford speculates that Judge Blair might have changed his mind about rulings that he made. Ford does not identify these rulings or offer any proof in support of its speculation. Ford has not shown that it was prejudiced by the substitution of Judge Murray for Judge Blair. Indeed, the record discloses that Judge Murray conducted the trial with full knowledge of the proceedings and without prejudice to either party. The decision to grant or deny a mistrial is ordinarily committed to the sound discretion of the trial judge. This general rule applies to diverse circumstances. See, e.g., Standard Industries, Inc. v. Mobil Oil Corp., 475 F.2d 220, 228-29 (10th Cir. 1973); Burger Chef Systems, Inc. v. Govro, 407 F.2d 921, 933 (8th Cir. 1969); Traders and General Insurance Co. v. Mallitz, 315 F.2d 171, 173-74 (5th Cir. 1963). Unquestionably, if Judge Murray had authority to proceed with the case, he exercised his discretion soundly in refusing to jettison three weeks of trial. The jury was available to continue with the trial. The testimony and other incidents of trial had been recorded. Although a daily transcript was not available, copies were ordered after Judge Blair's death for Judge Murray's use. He was able to master the intricacies of the controversy and to prepare intelligently to serve as a substitute for Judge Blair. Judge Murray's decision prejudiced no one. On the contrary, it properly utilized the services of the jury, conserved expenses to the parties and the government, and promoted the efficient administration of a busy court. The critical question, therefore, is not whether Judge Murray abused his discretion but whether the law authorized him to proceed with the trial. Before reaching the constitutional question which Ford raises, we must consider other grounds for decision. See Ashwander v. Tennessee Valley Authority, 297 U.S. 288, 347 (1936) (Brandeis, J.). No statute or rule expressly confers or denies authority for the substitution of a judge in a civil jury case. Although there are many decisions dealing with substitution in non-jury and criminal trials, no case precisely on point has been called to our attention.1 Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 63 provides: If by reason of death, sickness, or other disability, a judge before whom an action has been tried is unable to perform the duties to be performed by the court under these rules after a verdict is returned or findings of fact and conclusions of law are filed, then any other judge regularly sitting in or assigned to the court in which the action was tried may perform these duties; but if such other judge is satisfied that he cannot perform those duties because he did not preside at the trial or for any other reason, he may in his discretion grant a new trial. The rule does not expressly address the question of substitution in a jury trial before the verdict is returned. Moreover, the genesis of the rule demonstrates that it was not promulgated to address this subject. Section 953 of the Revised Statutes,2 enacted in 1872, provided for the authentication of a bill of exceptions by the judge of the court in which the cause was tried. This provision was interpreted in Malony v. Adsit, 175 U.S. 281, 285 (1899), to mean "that no bill of exceptions can be deemed sufficiently authenticated unless signed by the judge who sat at the trial...." In 1900, Congress, reacting to Malony, enacted a statute which allowed another judge to rule on a motion for a new trial or an application for allowance of a bill of exceptions in case of the death of the judge who had presided at the trial.3 See St. Louis Southwestern Railway Co. v. Henwood, 157 F.2d 337, 342 (8th Cir. 1946); 11 Wright and Miller, Federal Practice and Procedure § 2921. Rule 63 superseded this statute and extended it to include all of the duties performed by the judge after verdict or judgment. See Advisory Committee Note. Hence, Rule 63 was written to expand, not to restrict, the authority of another judge to proceed following the death of the initial trial judge. It is quite apparent, however, that a logical argument can be constructed to interpret the rule as impliedly prohibiting substitution before the jury returns its verdict. Nevertheless, relying on the evolution of the rule and recognizing that pragmatism is sometimes a surer guide than logic, we decline to enlarge the scope of the rule by resorting to implication. The proper course, it seems to us, is to leave the question of substitution to the sound discretion of the trial court. This is the approach taken in St. Louis Southwestern Railway Co. v. Henwood, 157 F.2d 337, 342 (8th Cir. 1946). There the issue arose in a bankruptcy proceeding where, as here, no rule expressly governed the question of substitution. For this reason, the court's reasoning is instructive: Theoretically and actually, a "Court" is a continuing and continuous institution.... Normally, matters therein flow uninterruptedly onward to finality. A change in personnel of judges during the course of litigation presents a problem of interruption. Such changes have occurred at different stages of suits and with varying results as to whether the successor judge could go forward or should retrace some of the ground travelled by his predecessor. An examination of the reasoning underlying the opinions and producing their results is convincing that the flow of a suit is interrupted by changes in personality of judges only where justice--for which courts exist--seems so to require. Unless justice demands something else, a different judge takes up litigation where the former judge left off. Where it is not done, it is, broadly, because of something in the past course of the litigation which cannot be found in the status and record existing when the new judge takes hold and which it is necessary for him, in all fairness to the parties, to know. Where it is necessary for him to gain this absent information, he must set back the litigation to the place where he can obtain it. How and by whom is the existence of such necessity to be determined? In some instances, the law speaks through some affirmative legal requirement.... In other instances, the successor judge has power, through the exercise of a reviewable judicial discretion, to determine on the situation in which he finds himself. Recognition that a court is a continuing institution places the question of substitution in its proper light. In the absence of an affirmative legal requirement, the propriety of substitution is committed to the discretion of the district judge as an aspect of his general authority pertaining to mistrials. In many instances, discretion should dictate a mistrial. In other cases, where the jury, the court, and the parties have invested substantial time and money in the trial and substitution can be made without prejudice, we perceive no sound reason for denying a judge the discretion to proceed with the trial after the death of his predecessor to whom the case had been initially assigned. In reaching this conclusion, we are influenced by the 1966 amendment to Rule of Federal Criminal Procedure 25. Subsection (a)4 was added to provide: If by reason of death, sickness or other disability the judge before whom a jury trial has commenced is unable to proceed with the trial, any other judge regularly sitting in or assigned to the court, upon certifying that he has familiarized himself with the record of the trial, may proceed with and finish the trial. Again, we realize that one can argue that the absence of a similar provision in the civil rules indicates that a judge in a civil case lacks the discretion to proceed that he has in a criminal case. Such an argument, though superficially appealing, overlooks the broad discretion that a judge has always exercised over mistrials in civil cases. Moreover, there are neither logical nor pragmatic reasons for allowing a criminal jury trial, involving the liberty and reputation of a person, to go forward after the death of the trial judge while a civil jury trial, involving the liberty and reputation of a person, to go forward after the death of the trial judge while a civil jury trial, involving lesser stakes, must inevitably grind to a halt. In sum, we recognize that a district court has broad discretion to deny mistrials in civil cases. No statute, rule, or controlling case law expressly prohibits it from exercising this authority when a judge presiding over a civil jury trial dies before the jury returns a verdict. We decline to engraft an implied prohibition of this nature on the civil rules, especially since such a prohibition would be contrary to the policy established by the criminal rules. Having determined that there is no non-constitutional bar to the action Judge Murray took, we turn to the issue Ford raises pertaining to the seventh amendment. Ford bases its constitutional argument on the well recognized principle that the right of trial by jury secured by the seventh amendment means trial by a jury under the superintendence of a judge. Relying on criminal cases that antedate the 1966 amendment to Rule 25,5 Ford contends that proceeding after the death of a trial judge by substituting another judge "contravenes the seventh amendment." We accept, of course, the proposition that trial by jury means a jury under the superintendence of a judge. See Capital Traction Co. v. Hof, 174 U.S. 1, 13-14 (1899). But we cannot accept Ford's argument that the seventh amendment requires a mistrial when the judge dies before the jury returns a verdict. The pertinent provision of the seventh amendment is: "In suits at common law... the right of trial by jury shall be preserved...." In Colgrove v. Battin, 413 U.S. 149 (1973), the Court held that this provision of the amendment did not require a jury of 12 persons. On the contrary, a jury of six, as provided by local rule of a district court, satisfied the seventh amendment. In reaching this conclusion the Court said, 413 U.S. at 156-57: Consistently with the historical objective of the Seventh Amendment, our decisions have defined the jury right preserved in cases covered by the Amendment, as "the substance of the common-law right of trial by jury, as distinguished from mere matters of form or procedure...." The Amendment, therefore, does not "bind the federal courts to the exact procedural incidents or details of jury trial according to the common law in 1791," and "[n]ew devices may be used to adapt the ancient institution to present needs and to make of it an efficient instrument in the administration of justice...." Applying these principles, we conclude that although a jury trial means a trial under superintendence of a judge, the seventh amendment does not require that the proceedings must be conducted by the same judge. Whether the trial may proceed after the death of a judge is not of "the substance of a common-law right of trial by jury." In the absence of demonstrable prejudice, substitution, in and of itself, does not impinge on the substantive rights of litigants to trial by jury. It raises a procedural question whose resolution may vary from case to case. Substitution is not forbidden by the seventh amendment. Substitution may be governed by statute, by rule, such as Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 25, or, as here, in the absence of these, by the sound discretion of the judge to whom the case has been reassigned. II The remaining assignments of error require a brief summary of the facts, which are set forth in detail in Judge Blair's opinion, Whalen v. Ford Motor Credit Co., 475 F. Supp. 537 (D. Md. 1979). Towson undertook to construct a high-rise condominium. It paid Ford a $195,000 non-refundable fee for a loan commitment under which Ford agreed to lend $9,750,000 for a period of two years after completion of the project. Ford's obligation was contingent on Towson's satisfying a number of conditions including completion of the building by March 1, 1975. The completion date was extended to September 1, 1975, in consideration of an additional fee of $48,750. Towson planned to repay Ford by the sale of condominiums during the two-year period of the loan. Towson next obtained a commitment from Equibank for a construction loan of $9,750,000. With the consent of Ford, Towson assigned Ford's commitment to Equibank. At the same time, Ford and Equibank entered into what financiers call a "buy-sell" agreement, under which Ford agreed to buy from Equibank, and Equibank agreed to sell, the construction loan in the amount of $9,750,000, provided Towson complied with all conditions of the commitment including completion of construction by September 1, 1975. On September 1, 1975, Ford declined to purchase the loan from Equibank, asserting that because the building was not complete, Towson had failed to satisfy conditions precedent for Ford's loan. Ford persisted in its refusal notwithstanding Equibank's previous offer to place in escrow funds amounting to 150% of the cost of tenant improvements as determined by Ford's inspector. Equibank sued Ford, and in settlement of this action it received a substantial sum for which it released Ford from liability to Equibank on Ford's commitment and the buy-sell agreement. Unable to pay Equibank without the proceeds of the Ford loan, Towson and its partners, who had guaranteed payment of the construction loan, were faced with foreclosure. They settled with Equibank by conveying the condominiums and several other parcels of land to Equibank. The guarantors gave a new note payable in 30 months or "upon conclusion of Towson's suit against Ford." Equibank assumed liability for certain obligations Towson owed to subcontractors. Towson then brought this action against Ford, alleging breach of both the loan commitment and the For-Equibank buy-sell agreement. Towson claimed that its settlement with Equibank constituted a reassignment of the Ford loan commitment from Equibank to Towson or a revocation of the original assignment. Ford moved for summary judgment, contending that Towson's assignment of Ford's commitment to Equibank and the subsequent settlement of Equibank's action against Ford barred Towson from suing Ford for breach of the commitment. Judge Blair denied Ford's motion for summary judgment. He held that the assignment of the commitment, though absolute on its face, actually was made to provide security for Equibank's construction loan. Additionally, Judge Blair held that Towson was a third-party beneficiary of Ford's agreement to buy the Equibank construction loan. We affirm Judge Blair's denial of summary judgment for reasons adequately stated in his opinion, Whalen v. Ford Motor Credit Co., 475 F. Supp. 537, 539-40 (D. Md. 1979). In a subsequent pre-trial ruling, without opinion, Judge Blair held that as a matter of law Towson's action was not barred, in effect granting summary judgment for Towson on this issue. Ford protests that it was entitled to submit this issue to the jury for ascertainment of the parties' intentions in making the assignment and executing the buy-sell agreement. It relies on proffered testimony of Equibank's attorney to the effect that the assignment was intended to vest in Equibank all of Towson's right, title, and interest in the Ford commitment. Because Judge Blair summarily refused, without an opinion, to submit this issue to the jury, we will briefly address it. We conclude that Judge Blair properly determined that there was no genuine issue of material fact concerning Towson's right to maintain this action and that, consequently, Towson was entitled to summary judgment on this issue. Towson had paid Ford nearly a quarter of a million dollars for Ford's loan commitment. When Towson assigned this commitment to Equibank, and Ford and Equibank entered into the buy-sell agreement of the construction loan, the parties contemplated, as evidenced by the contemporaneously executed documents, that Towson would retain its interest in the project subject to its liability to Equibank and its potential liability to Ford. Equibank was fully apprised that the source of payment for its construction loan was the Ford commitment. Prudent banking therefore dictated that it take an assignment of this commitment for the purpose of securing repayment of the funds it advanced for construction. The testimony of Equibank's counsel, on which Ford relies, must be read in the context of his explanation of the purpose of the assignment. He said: "Well, as additional security for the loan and in order to be able to be put in the borrower's place, we require generally an assignment of the permanent commitment [Ford], from the borrower [Towson] to our client, the construction lender [Equibank]." Under Maryland law, an assignment absolute on its face may be shown by parole evidence actually to have been made as collateral security. Hodgson v. Burroughs, 175 Md. 413, 426-27, 2 A.2d 407, 413 (1938). Equibank confirmed the assignment's role as security by recognizing Towson's cause of action against Ford in its settlement agreement with Towson. This agreement, which discharged Towson's obligation to Equibank, operated as a reassignment of the commitment to Ford. 4 Corbin, Contracts § 881 (1951). Towson retained an interest in the commitment sufficient to establish its status as a real party in interest under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 17(a). 6 Wright and Miller, Federal Practice and Procedure § 1545. Apart from the question of the assignment, there ia also no genuine issue of fact concerning Towson's status as a third-party beneficiary of the Ford-Equibank buy-sell agreement. As Judge Blair explained in Whalen v. Ford Motor Credit Co., 475 F. Supp. 537, 540 (D. Md. 1979), this agreement was intended to facilitate the execution of Ford's commitment to provide Towson permanent financing for the project. Since Towson alleged that Ford breached this agreement, it was entitled to maintain this action. See St. Paul at Chase Corp. v. Manufacturers Life Insurance Co., 262 Md. 192, 231-34, 278 A.2d 12, 31-32 (1971). We therefore conclude that the district court properly held as a matter of law that Towson could sue Ford under either Ford's loan commitment or as a third-party beneficiary of the Ford-Equibank agreement. III Ford's principal defense is that Towson did not satisfy the conditions of the loan commitment by September 1, 1975. These conditions included: (1) Satisfaction of the requirement that "all buildings and improvements on the property shall be completed;" (2) Delivery of "the architect's certificate to the effect that the improvements contemplated by the commitment have been completed;" (3) Delivery of "a certificate of occupancy" for the improvements; and (4) Satisfaction of the requirement that "all construction shall be of good quality". Ford contends that "completion" requires full performance of the contract, satisfaction of the punch list, and correction of all known deficiencies--in short, 100% completion. In support of its position, Ford correctly points out that it is undisputed that on September 1, 1975, the project was not fully completed and the architect gave only a certificate of partial occupancy. Moreover, the first floor, which was intended for commercial tenants, and the top floor, which was intended for penthouse units, had not been finished. Towson contends that the commitment required only substantial completion. It also asserts that the parties understood that the commercial space on the first floor and the penthouses on the top floor were to be designed by the tenants. According to Towson, the parties contemplated that these spaces would not be finished until the architect and the tenants agreed on the plans for these floors. Ford raised the issue of completion by motion for summary judgment, by a motion for a directed verdict, and by objection to instructions charging the jury that substantial completion satisfied the conditions of the commitment. Judge Blair denied Ford's motion for summary judgment. In his opinion he fully addressed the contentions of the parties and concluded that substantial completion satisfied the conditions of the commitment. At the same time he denied Towson's motion for summary judgment, noting that conflicting evidence raised a question of fact concerning the claim that the project was substantially completed by September 1, 1975. Judge Blair's opinion is supported by the authorities on which he relied.6 In contrast, Ford has not cited any case in which a permanent lender's refusal to honor its commitment was held to be justified because the project was only substantially completed. Accordingly, we affirm the denial of Ford's motions for summary judgment and directed verdict for reasons adequately stated in Judge Blair's opinion. Whalen v. Ford Motor Credit Co., 475 F. Supp. 537, 540-52 (D. Md. 1979). In view of the conflicting evidence about the state of completion and the quality of construction, Judge Murray submitted these questions to the jury under proper instructions that placed the burden of proof on Towson. He also explained to the jury the contentions of the parties concerning the unfinished floors and then instructed the jury on this issue: If you conclude from all the evidence and the conduct of the parties that the first floor and penthouse units were not to be completed until sold, even if that did not take place until after September second, 1975, then the incompletion of those units cannot be asserted by Ford as a ground for not funding. On the other hand, if you find Ford had sound ground to believe that those units should be completed by September second, it could constitute a basis for not funding if the state of incompletion was such as to significantly affect its security and completion could not be had in a reasonable time. Answering interrogatories on the questions of substantial completion and the quality of construction, the jury returned a verdict in favor of Towson. Having carefully considered Ford's several assignments of error pertaining to these issues and its objections to the court's instructions, we find no cause for reversal either of fact or law in this aspect of the case. IV Judge Murray instructed the jury that if it found that Ford breached its loan commitment, Towson would be entitled to recover as damages all reasonably incurred development costs that it put into the project up to the time of the conveyance to Equibank. The judge fully explained the elements of these damages and how they were to be computed. He cautioned that Towson could recover only for loss reasonably foreseeable from Ford's failure to fund its commitment. He also instructed the jury to consider Towson's receipts as offsets to its development costs. He set forth the contentions of the parties with respect to damages, and he explained to the jury the factual issues they should resolve. Further, he instructed the jury about Towson's burden of proof and its duty to mitigate its damages. Ford's principal assignment of error asserts that the court improperly excluded evidence demonstrating that even if Ford had supplied the funds to finance the project, Towson would have sustained greater losses because the market for condominiums was depressed. Because of these circumstances, Ford contends, Towson's equity in the project was destroyed and it was not entitled to recoup any of its development costs. In support of its position, Ford relies on Restatement (First) of Contracts § 333(d), which provides that if performance would have resulted in a net loss to the plaintiff, the amount of loss must be deducted from the plaintiff's expenditures. Ford cites cases applying this principle to contracts in general. We cannot accept Ford's position. Apart from the speculative nature of the proof of Towson's ultimate losses, Ford's reliance on § 333 of the Restatement is misplaced. Ford's commitment was a contract to lend money. Damages for breach of this kind of contract are addressed in § 343 of the Restatement. As explained in Illustration 3 of this section, when, as here, the borrower cannot obtain alternative financing for the construction of a building, he can obtain judgment "for the amount of his expenditures on the building." Ford's position is fundamentally wrong. It would improperly permit a permanent lender, who has been paid a substantial commitment fee to assume the risk of a project's viability, to dishonor its commitment with impunity if, after construction has been substantially completed, the project is shown to be unprofitable. See First National State Bank v. Commonwealth Federal Savings & Loan Association, 610 F.2d 164, 173-74 (3d Cir. 1979). Under such a rule it is unlikely that any developer could obtain a construction loan. Judge Murray properly rejected Ford's proffer as irrelevant, and he correctly instructed the jury on the measure and elements of recovery. See St. Paul at Chase Corp. v. Manufacturers Life Insurance Co., 262 Md. 192, 278 A.2d 12 (1971). His allocation of the risk of loss is consistent with the theory of the leading cases on this subject. See, e.g., First National State Bank v. Commonwealth Federal Savings & Loan Association, 610 F.2d 164 (3d Cir. 1980); Mellon Bank, N.A. v. Aetna Business Credit, Inc., 468 F. Supp. 656 (W.D. Pa. 1979); Pipkin v. Thomas & Hill, Inc., 258 S.E.2d 778 (N.C. 1979); Selective Builders, Inc. v. Hudson City Savings Bank, 137 N.J. Super. 500, 349 A.2d 564 (1975); St. Paul at Chase Corp. v. Manufacturers Life Insurance Co., supra. We find no grounds for reversal in Ford's assignments of error pertaining to specific elements of damage and to the jury's allowance and the court's computation of pre-judgment interest. The judgment of the district court is affirmed. MURNAGHAN, Circuit Judge, dissenting: I. It is trite, but true that civil cases proceed either before the court or before a jury. It is equally true that the procedure is governed, in either case, by the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. See F.R. Civ. P. 1. Those rules customarily approach each procedural situation on a composite basis, setting out a uniform procedure to govern, in the same fashion, except to the extent specifically modified, judge trials and jury trials alike. As an example of specific modification see Rule 51 (Instructions to the Jury: Objection) and Rule 52 (Findings by the Court). They deal with the inescapable difference that the jury returns a coalescence, a verdict, which is the unanimous, joint effort of six, whereas a judge, acting by himself, individually produces findings of fact and conclusions of law. The more customary composite rule designed to eliminate distinctions between jury and non-jury procedures is exemplified by Rule 58 (Entry of Judgment) ("... upon a general verdict of a jury, or upon a decision by the court... the clerk... shall forthwith prepare, sign, and enter the judgment without awaiting any direction by the court;"). The Rule which here governs is F.R. Civ. P. 63 (Disability of a Judge). It is clearly a composite rule: If by reason of death, sickness, or other disability, a judge before whom an action has been tried is unable to perform the duties to be performed by the court under these rules after a verdict is returned or findings of fact and conclusions of law are filed, then any other judge regularly sitting in or assigned to the court in which the action was tried may perform those duties; but if such other judge is satisfied that he cannot perform those duties because he did not preside at the trial or for any other reason, he may in his discretion grant a new trial. The question presented is a simple one to state, if the answer is not without its complexities: May, over the objection of one of the parties, the district court require a case being tried before a jury to continue, with a new judge substituted, where the initial judge has died after the case has commenced, but before the taking of evidence has been completed and a verdict has been returned? The authorities are uniform, consistently giving a negative response to the question, and holding that the case must be tried again de novo, wherever Rule 63 governs. Arrow-Hart, Inc. v. Philip Carey Co., 552 F.2d 711 (6th Cir. 1977) ("However, in the absence of unanimous agreement of the parties, and where, as here, there is no oral or written expression of the deceased judge reasonably satisfying the requirements of Rule 52 concerning findings of fact and conclusions of law, we hold that a new trial is required and that Judge(Word Illegible) was correct in his construction of Rule 63"); Bromberg v. Moul, 275 F.2d 574 (2d Cir. 1960) ("The case was tried by Judge Knight without a jury in March, 1955, and soon after he died without having made any findings or decision.... It is plain that this rule (Rule 63) is inapplicable [insofar as permitting continuance with a substitute judge was concerned] since no findings of fact and conclusions of law were filed."); Brennan v. Grisso, 198 F.2d 532 (D.C. Cir. 1952) ("The late Judge Goldsborough heard the case without a jury. He expressed orally the belief that appellant had not been domiciled in Florida and that the divorce was invalid. He filed no findings of fact or conclusions of law and no opinion or memorandum. On June 6, 1951, he said 'the bill of complaint is dismissed', but he did not order judgment to be entered and judgment was not entered.... The Rule [Rule 63] thus shows a generous attitude toward a new trial when the trial judge dies before the case is disposed of.... In view of these considerations, we think Rule 63 should not be interpreted so broadly as to dispense with the necessity of a new trial upon the death of the trial judge."); Ten-O-Win Amusement Co. v. Casino Theatre, 2 F.R.D. 242 (N.D. Calif. 1942) (The judge had announced a decision in favor of plaintiff, entering judgment "upon the filing of approved findings of fact and conclusions of law." After setting out the text of Rule 63, the court stated: "The language of the rule seems clear and no Federal case has been found interpreting it.... As findings of fact and conclusions of law herein were not 'filed' by Judge LOUDERBACK before his death, I have no power to sign and file them now. A new trial will be therefore granted as to defendant Donohue."). Cf. Havey v. Kropp, 458 F.2d 1054 (6th Cir. 1972) ("The case was thoroughly briefed, argued and was submitted, but the District Judge died without announcing a decision. It was subsequently discovered that he had prepared what appeared to be an opinion in final form granting the writ of habeas corpus, but since it had not been filed the case was assigned to another judge. The second judge, being of the view that one issue of fact existed, held a limited evidentiary hearing and further argument, and then filed an opinion denying habeas corpus relief and dismissing the petition. This appeal was perfected from that order, and in the argument above referred to, appellant urges that the second District Judge should have, as a matter of law, filed or caused to be filed the opinion and order of her deceased colleague. Appellant offers no direct authority in support of this argument, but urges that under Rule 63, Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, (which we conclude to be without application), the deceased judge's opinion could have been filed and judgment entered.... We hold that Judge Kennedy, from whose order the present appeal was perfected, was not required as a matter of law to file or be bound by the unfiled draft,..."). It should not surprise us that Rule 63 has been consistently and uniformly read in the same way to reach the same result. As a simple matter of language, what else is a rule to be taken to mean when it states that another judge may substitute for a deceased judge "after a verdict is returned or findings of fact and conclusions of law are filed?" It unambiguously indicates that the power of substitution is not conferred where the death occurs before a verdict is returned or findings of fact and conclusions of law are filed. Nothing in the rule intimates that the result should differ depending whether a verdict or a judge's findings are involved. To the contrary, the rule expressly calls for the same treatment. For the majority opinion to prevail, there would have to be an expansion of, or a deletion in the language of, Rule 63. Either it must be expanded to allow substitution of a new judge for the deceased judge "before or after a verdict is returned or findings of fact and conclusions of law are filed." Or, in the alternative, there must be an excision from the rule of the terminology "after a verdict is returned or findings of fact and conclusions of law are filed." The Rule would then state: If by reason of death, sickness or other disability, a judge before whom an action has been tried is unable to perform the duties to be performed by the court under these rules [deletion of 15 words], then any other judge regularly sitting in or assigned to the court in which the action was tried may perform those duties. The principle requires no elaboration that the function of a panel of the Court, or, indeed, of the Court en banc, is to apply the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure as written, and not to amend or modify them. 2 Moore's Federal Practice P1.13[1] ("(T)he provisions of the Rules are to be observed by all.").1 The majority seeks to distinguish, on the grounds that they were non-jury cases, Arrow-Hart, supra, and the other authorities, all of which construe Rule 63 in a fashion contrary to the result they reach. But, to proceed in that fashion is to encounter several insuperable obstacles. F.R. Civ. P. 2 states that there shall be one form of action. Professor Moore construes it to mean: All procedural distinctions between actions at law and suits in equity and in the forms of action and practice and procedure thereof are abolished, and hereafter there shall be only one form of civil action. 2 Moore, supra, P2.02[1]. Nothing in Rule 63 suggests that its consequences are to differ depending on whether the judge's death occurs before the return of a verdict, on the one hand, or before the filing of findings of fact and conclusions of law, on the other. To the contrary, Rule 63 plainly mandates like treatment. See 6A Moore's Federal Practice (2d ed.) P59.08[2]: The death... of a judge during a trial and before a verdict is returned in a jury case or before findings of fact and conclusion are made in a court case will, in the absence of the consent of all parties, normally result in a mistrial. If the disability thereafter occurs, then a successor judge may, pursuant to Rule 63, decide a motion for new trial or other post-verdict motion, if he can properly perform his duty in relation thereto; otherwise he should grant a new trial. According to the majority, the result they reach is justified by the avoidance of the jettisoning of three weeks of trial, by proper utilization of the services of the jury, the conservation of expenses to the parties and the government, and the promotion of the efficient administration of a busy court.2 Yet such considerations were present in spades in Arrow-Hart, supra, and they were insufficient to persuade the Sixth Circuit to disregard Rule 63. See 552 F.2d at 711-12: The case was tried before United States District Judge Mac Swinford, sitting without a jury, in 1974, and required 19 trial days and an additional 18 days for depositions. At the end of the testimony, Judge Swinford prescribed a schedule for filing briefs after the completion of the transcript. After the transcript of approximately 5,000 pages had been completed, but before all the briefs were filed, Judge Swinford died on February 3, 1975, without having made any findings of fact or conclusions of law. The case was reassigned to District Judge Eugene E. Siler, Jr. The plaintiffs and four of the five defendants filed a motion with Judge Siler urging as follows: 1. To decide the case on the transcript of the former trial without necessitating another trial. 2. If there has to be a second trial, to allow transcripts from the prior trial to be used the same as depositions of witnesses who otherwise qualify, that is, under Rule 32(a)(3), Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, where they either live outside the Eastern District of Kentucky, or reside one hundred miles from the place of holding the trial, or cannot be procured otherwise by the parties. 3. If a second trial is necessary, to allow the same witnesses to adopt their prior transcribed testimony by reference in accordance with Rule 803(5) or (24), Federal Rules of Evidence, limiting cross-examination to any new matters raised. Philip Carey Co., the fifth defendant, refused to agree that Judge Siler decide the case on the transcript of the former trial without necessitating another trial, and insisted that the death of Judge Swinford without having made findings of fact and conclusions of law necessitates a new trial. At a pre-trial conference, the parties indicated that they would expect to use the same witnesses who testified at the prior trial, and that a second trial would be expected to last as long as the first. 552 F.2d at 712: In a memorandum opinion filed May 6, 1976, Judge Siler said: The undersigned Judge is satisfied that he can render judgment on the prior transcript and upon any additional testimony that may be presented, but he feels that he has no discretion in the matter. This court requested that the local attorney for Philip Carey communicate with house counsel for the corporation and ascertain if it would be possible to reach an agreement to that effect. We have been informed by Cincinnati counsel that the request of the court was submitted to the client, along with a summary of the court's comments, and that Philip Carey has instructed its attorney that he is not authorized to change the position taken by the corporation in the District Court and in this court. The records of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts show that 2,308 cases, criminal and civil, were filed in the Eastern District of Kentucky during the calendar year 1976, a total of 769 cases per judge, and that the District Court has a backlog of 3,232 civil and criminal cases pending on December 31, 1976. In the face of this staggering caseload, we are reluctant to hold that District Judge Siler does not have the discretion to dispose of the present case on the basis of the evidence on file, together with any additional competent evidence that the parties may desire to submit. However, in the absence of unanimous agreement of the parties, and where, as here, there is no oral or written expression of the deceased judge reasonably satisfying the requirements of Rule 52 concerning findings of fact and conclusions of law, we hold that a new trial is required and that Judge Siler was correct in his construction of Rule 63.3 The long and the short of it is that the majority dislikes Rule 63, at least as it affects the instant case, and so would abrogate it. The argument they advance is that the generally wide, and liberally provided discretion of the trial judge, here Judge Murray, should not be disturbed where he elected to continue the trial, even though Judge Blair, who had conducted three weeks of it, died before the taking of evidence was completed and before a verdict was returned. Instances of wide discretion conferred on the district judge are cited in (a) the grant of a mistrial because of "improper voluntary statements of a witness," (b) denial of a mistrial where counsel made an unwarranted appeal to the jury's sympathies and a curative statement by the judge was made, and (c) denial of a mistrial where the judge, in response to a jury's query informed the jury that the matter was not in its bailiwick and not to concern itself about the matter.4 With respect those cases do not engage Rule 63, and are simply not relevant. The distinction is that no provision of the Federal Rules forecloses a trial judge's exercise of discretion relative to a grant of mistrial for improper witness statements, unprofessional conduct of counsel or a jury's attempt to range outside its area of responsibility. Rule 63, however, forecloses any exercise of discretion to continue a case with a substituted judge where the original judge has died before return of verdict or filing of findings of fact and conclusions of law. The significance of that consideration is made altogether clear by the very case by which the majority seeks to justify its conclusion that a retrial de novo was not mandated. St. Louis South-Western Ry. v. Henwood, 157 F.2d 337 (8th Cir. 1946), cert. denied, 330 U.S. 836 (1947), rehearing denied, 331 U.S. 870 (1947).5 The district court was considering whether to approve a plan for the reorganization of a railroad debtor. The evidence had been closed and arguments of counsel were being made. All parties had presented arguments in chief except one party to the proceedings appearing pro se and except for the debtor. At that point the judge died. Only the party appearing pro se objected to the adoption of the record as completed before the deceased judge, and demanded a complete new trial. The Eighth Circuit concluded, there being no Rule 63 involved, that the discretion of the district court extended so far as to permit the successor to proceed on the record "as it came to him." However, it emphasized that the discretion could be curtailed by specific provision of law. At 157 F.2d at 342, it stated: How and by whom is the existence of such necessity to be determined? In some instances, the law speaks through some affirmative legal requirement. Malony v. Adsit, 175 U.S. 281, 20 S. Ct. 115, 44 L. Ed. 163, changed by 31 Stat. 270, 28 U.S.C.A. § 776. In other instances, the successor judge has power, through the exercise of a reviewable judicial discretion, to determine on the situation in which he finds himself. The very example it cited of "some affirmative legal requirement" which would preempt the trial judge's exercise of discretion was a statute requiring that the judge sitting at the trial sign the bill of exceptions. The statute, as the quotation from Henwood makes clear, was supplanted by 28 U.S.C.A. § 776. The Advisory Committee on the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure appended a note to Rule 63 stating: This rule adapts and extends the provisions of U.S.C.A., Title 28, former § 776 (Bill of exceptions; authentication; signing of by judge) to include all duties to be performed by the judge after verdict or judgment. The statute is therefore superseded. Thus Henwood, the case on which the majority rests its proposition that there is discretion in the trial judge to continue the trial despite death of the presiding judge in the midst thereof, prior to the return of the verdict, notwithstanding the blatantly contrary phraseology of Rule 63, itself asserts that the statutory predecessor of Rule 63 would constrain the exercise of discretion. In effect it says that to contradict the requirement of the statute (and inexorably, therefore, of its extension Rule 63) would amount to an abuse of discretion.6 Even so, argue the majority, the language of Rule 63 only states what can be done when there has been a return of verdict, or a filing of findings of fact and conclusions of law. It does not, they contend, explicitly state what can be done when there has been no return of verdict, no filing of findings of fact and conclusions of law.7 That approach would disrupt language as a means for communication. The implication that there may not be a substitution to replace a deceased judge and to continue the trial if death comes before return of verdict is inescapable. See 7 Moore's Federal Practice P63.05 at p. 63-9; In re Schoenfield, 608 F.2d 930, 934 (2d Cir. 1979). Moreover, the slight vestige of life one can, by assiduous pumping, squeeze into that theory depends, it would seem, on there having been, before adoption of the Federal Rules, a rule generally allowing to a trial court a discretion to substitute another judge at any time, before or after verdict, for a judge who had died. Yet there simply was no such rule. The surprisingly scant authority perhaps reflects the happy infrequency of death occurring to presiding judges during the course of trials.8 What precedents there are establish that the widely held belief was that death of the judge mandated a fully de novo proceeding. Since that was the case, it simply is not plausible or possible to think that the Advisory Committee on the Federal Rules operated in an atmosphere where the idea of resuscitating and continuing a trial, aborted during gestation and prior to delivery, had any currency. Consider the rule for criminal cases, overhung as such cases have been with problems of double jeopardy. If the first trial could continue under a substitute judge, the manifest necessity for declaring a mistrial and placing the accused in jeopardy a second time would not exist. Yet, "[a]t common law, if in a trial for felony a juror, the judge, or the prisoner becomes incapacitated by illness after the jury are impaneled and sworn in chief, the proper course is to declare a mistrial and begin de novo." 76 Am. Jur. 2d (Trial) § 1092. See State v. Slorah, 118 Me. 203, 209, 106 Atl. 768, 771 (1919): Certain conditions, if arising in the trial of a case, have come to be well recognized as constituting that "urgent necessity" which will warrant the discharge of a jury, and, if they appear of record, will bar a plea of former jeopardy: ... (2) illness of the court, a member of the jury, or the respondent.... Cf. Annotation, Substitution of Judge in Criminal Case, 83 A.L.R.2d 1032, 1034, 1036 (1962) ("A substitution of judges during the introduction of evidence, over the objection of the accused, has been held to be error."). There had been general acceptance at least until the time of adoption of F.R. Civ. P. 63 and of F.R. Crim. P. 25(a) in 1966, that the trial de novo was, in the absence of the defendant's consent constitutionally mandated. Wright, Federal Practice and Procedure: Criminal § 392 (1969): In the absence of consent,... the death or disability of the judge requires that a mistrial be granted.9 Cf. Freeman v. United States, 227 Fed. 732, 759-60 (2d Cir. 1915); Bailey v. Indiana, 397 N.E.2d 1024, 1027 (Ind. App. 1979) (criminal trial). The English attitude should be entitled weight in determining what the rule was at common law, i.e. before the advent of such innovations as F.R. Civ. P. 63. The British authorities support the conclusion that, on Judge Blair's death, a trial de novo was required. In Coleshill v. Manchester Corp., [1928] 1 K.B. 785, a jury trial, three witnesses were called before the presiding judge. He died and the case was resumed 4 days later before the same jury but, necessarily, another judge. That procedure was approved by the trial court "at the urgent request of the parties."10 Naturally, therefore, on appeal there was no point made by either party as to any impropriety of the procedure. Nevertheless, Scrutton, J. felt it incumbent on him sua sponte to observe: ... I think it is a precedent which should not be followed in the future. I doubt whether a judge has any jurisdiction to continue the hearing of a case in which witnesses have been called in court in the course of the trial before the jury and another judge.... That observation, if nothing else, provides strong indication that, prior to 1928, in British courts, it was universally accepted that, even with the consent of the parties--and a fortiori without--continuance of a jury trial with a substituted judge, upon the death of the one who had commenced the case, was not permitted at common law. No subsequent development in the British courts draws that conclusion into doubt.11 It seems to me too pat for the majority to seek to dismiss as irrelevant the consideration that Judge Murray did not see the witnesses testify. Slip op. at 2-3: "This difference is immaterial, for it was the function of the jury, not the trial judge, to assess the credibility of the witnesses." That flat statement ignores the judge's function to comment upon credibility. See Supreme Court Standard 107 "... the judge may fairly and impartially sum up the evidence and comment to the jury upon the weight of the evidence and the credibility of the witnesses...." Standard 107 was not incorporated into the Federal Rules of Evidence upon the recognition "that the formulation adopted by the Supreme Court [Rule 105], Standard 107 did represent the clear federal law...." "Congress struck it without intending to change the federal practice." 1 Weinstein's Evidence, p. 107-2. How can a judge fully resolve the question of whether such a particular comment on credibility should be made, how can a judge determine whether he should correct, as erroneous, a statement of counsel relating to the demeanor, traits or behavior of a witness, unless he has been present to observe the conduct of the witness? See Mason v. State, 26 Oh. C.C. 535 (1904) quoted in Annotation, Authority of Judge in Respect of Unfinished Business of Another Judge, 54 A.L.R. 952, 960 (1928): Arguments of counsel to the jury should be based upon the evidence, and be restricted to what was proven. Counsel should not be permitted to distort and misstate the evidence, and yet the presiding judge from the record had no knowledge of what the evidence was whatever. But if we were to assume that the trial judge had read the evidence the result would be the same. The appearance and demeanor of the witnesses upon the stand are very important factors in weighing evidence, and give counsel not only a great field for argument, but in many cases for misrepresentation and improper denunciation. Did counsel fairly and properly represent the appearance and demeanor of the witnesses upon the stand in their arguments? ... The duties of the judge who took the place of the previous one required judgment in all these matters, and it seems to us that, where judgment is required in the performance of the duties of the trial judge in reference to the facts, one judge cannot be substituted for another during the trial, although under the law the judge so acting under such change may have the same jurisdiction and power as the disabled judge. (Emphasis supplied.) Moreover, the judge has responsibilities requiring full familiarity with all the evidence irrespective of the assignment to the jury of the duty to find the facts. The judge must also make a factual finding as to whether there is sufficient evidence to submit a case, or one or more aspect of it to the jury. Such findings were required here by the motion for directed verdict, and, as already pointed out, Judge Murray's hurried attempts to indoctrinate himself were no substitute for the full familiarization, ranging over a period of over 4 years, which the defendant would have received had Judge Blair not died. The difference in the two radically different constructs: one a careful, measured approach to the numerous knotty legal problems by Judge Blair, the other an inescapably hasty treatment by Judge Murray,12 with little or no opportunity for reflection and absorption reveals that, on any comparative basis, Ford Credit did not receive as fair a trial as it would have had if Judge Blair had not died. Considerations like these have recently led the First Circuit to apply Rule 63 by analogy to require a trial de novo, even though the case arose in bankruptcy, and Rule 63, accordingly was not controlling. In Re Schoenfield, 608 F.2d 930, 933 (1st Cir. 1979). We have described in some detail these Second Circuit decisions involving the substitution of judges in order to make clear that although the situation is rare, the legal principle guiding this Court's approach to such cases is basic and familiar. That principle, simply stated, is that the factfinder who is given the opportunity to observe witnesses as they testify is in a better position to make factual findings based on that evidence than is the factfinder who is restricted to a written record of the same testimony. Even before the study of "body language" came into vogue, it was recognized that transcripts of testimonial evidence--which cannot capture the sweaty brow, the shifty eye, the quavering voice--never fully reflect what was communicated by the testifying witness. 608 F.2d at 935. The question which confronts us relates to a civil trial, not a criminal one. We consequently are not directly concerned with what the result would be if the case were governed, not by F.R. Civ. P. 63, but by F.R. Crim. P. 25. Nevertheless, the procedure in criminal cases affords instructive analogies and indicate as to how to resolve the issue in a civil case. In the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, Rule 25 deals with the topic "Judge; Disability." Prior to an amendment in 1966, what is now Rule 25(b) was all of Rule 25. It, with minor language variations of no significance to the point with which we are concerned, tracked the language of F.R. Civ. P. 63 and provided that if: by reason of absence, death, sickness or other disability the judge before whom the defendant has been tried is unable to perform the duties to be performed by the court after a verdict or finding of guilt, any other judge... may perform those duties. Thus, before the 1966 amendment to the Criminal Rules, the same arguments already advanced in this dissent as to civil cases could be tellingly made that substitution of a new judge to replace one who had died was not possible when the judge's death had occurred prior to rendition of the jury verdict. That argument, strong as it already was, became substantially even stronger when, in 1966, a new section (a) was added to F.R. Crim. P. 25 providing that substitution of a judge might occur during trial. One must ask why, if the rule so provided all along, the amendment to introduce F.R. Crim. P. 25(a) was called for. And if it was in fact necessary, the failure to make a comparable amendment to the Civil Rules only reinforces a conclusion that proceeding over the objection of a party when the judge has died in the midst of a civil proceeding is not permitted. An appellee has suggested in its brief that it "is illogical if a district judge, because of death, may be replaced during the course of a criminal trial, where a defendant's liberty is at stake" yet, "such replacement would be impermissible in a civil trial where mere property hangs in the balance." However, a criminal trial, unlike a civil one, engages the serious hardships of jeopardy for a defendant. Death of the presiding judge while the case is in progress would almost certainly constitute "manifest necessity" permitting a retrial if no procedure for substitution existed. See, e.g., State v. Slorah, supra. But because a procedure may be legal does not mean that it is incapable of improvement. The purpose of F.R. Crim. P. 25(a) may have principally been to allow a defendant to avoid the unhappy situation where he would be forced to stand trial twice, yet not constitutionally have been subjected to double jeopardy. He was afforded the opportunity to go forward with a substituted judge. No similar reason, of course, exists in a trial on the civil side of the court. Hence amendment of the criminal rule without a corresponding amendment of the civil rule was altogether logical. Simply and summarily put, a trial tried partly before one judge, partly before another, just cannot afford the same scope for understanding to the second judge which one judge hearing the entire trial would have. The majority asserts that "pragmatism is sometimes a surer guide than logic." Inviting as that sounds, it translates, in the instant case, to "If you prefer a result, ignore the language which precludes it." In effect, the majority says to Ford Credit: "You rely at your peril on the Rules, for they may mean the opposite of what they say." The proper procedure to attain the result preferred by the majority is to amend the Federal Rules. It is not to assign a patently unsupportable intendment to the Rules as they now stand. Ohio was faced with the exact same situation. Prior to July 1, 1972, Ohio's Rule of Civil Procedure 63 fully adopted F.R. Civ. P. 63, specifically including the phrase "after a verdict is returned or findings of fact and conclusions of law are filed." A Staff Note on Ohio Rule 63 as it then stood, Page's Ohio Rev. Code Ann., Civil Rules vol., stated: Note that the rule is a rule of ministerial convenience; that is, one judge may not replace another judge during the middle of the actual trial; the replacement of the judge is permissible under the rule only after the findings of fact and conclusions of law have been filed or the jury verdict has been returned. Ohio did not seek by judicial decision to abrogate Rule 63, whose meaning was pellucid. Instead, it did what was required and amended the rule specifically to permit substitution during a jury trial. Welsh v. Brown-Graves Lumber Co., 58 Oh. App. 2d 49, 389 N.E.2d 514 (1978). The Staff Note on the change observed that "Rule 63, governing replacement of a disabled judge during the course of a civil action, has been substantially amended by the addition of a subdivision (A)." It simply does not lie in our power, as a federal appeals court, to effect, in the course of adjudicating a case, a substantial amendment to the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Thus, I dissent from the failure to direct a full trial de novo. II. However, that question properly should not even have been presented to us, for the district court erred in not granting Ford Credit's motion for a directed verdict, or motion for summary judgment because of the failure of Towson Associates Limited Partnership ("the Limited Partnership") even to make efforts to complete the first floor and the penthouse floor. The trial judge put to the jury the issue of whether "from all the evidence and the conduct of the parties" "the first floor and penthouse units were not to be completed until sold." It added that if, contractually, Ford Credit was entitled to expect completion by the critical date of September 2, 1975, it would be justified in not funding "if the state of incompletion was such as to significantly affect its security and completion could not be had in a reasonable time." There was, however, simply no sufficient evidence to support a factual conclusion that Ford Credit, unmistakably having secured an undertaking of completion by September 2, 1975,13 ever modified it to permit delay of the first floor and penthouse items until sold. Moreover, in the circumstances of unilateral action by the Limited Partnership to abandon any efforts or pretense at completion of the first floor and penthouse, Ford Credit was freed of any obligation to fund once September 2, 1975 passed, and was not obliged to allow a reasonable extension of time for completion. Perhaps Polonius knew whereof he spoke in advising his son to steer clear of borrowing and of lending. They have brought the participants in the case before us to a pretty pass. Although the Limited Partnership agreed to the condition precedent contained in the take-out loan commitment from Ford Credit that all buildings and improvements shall be diligently prosecuted to completion in accordance with plans and specifications therefor, and although the plans and specifications indicated details for finishing the first floor and penthouse of the condominium building, nevertheless, from the very outset, from a time prior to the execution of the take-out loan commitment, the Limited Partnership had no intention of completing the first floor and penthouse and, in fact, did not complete them. The Limited Partnership has contended that Ford Credit understood, approved, and consented to the intentions of the Limited Partnership only to rough in, not to complete, the first floor and penthouse. Yet, as to that, the following matters developed by the record are most perplexing: 1. There is simply no place in the Joint Appendix where such consent by Ford Credit is testified to or otherwise established. The closest that the record comes was the testimony of Cornelius M. Whalen, the general partner of the Limited Partnership, that it made a decision "concerning the use of the first floor" before the drawings were even started and that he had a discussion in depth "concerning the professional space on the first floor" with Ford Credit at the time an application for a take-out loan commitment was first made. Cornelius M. Whalen also stated that he made "the decision concerning the penthouse units," that it was made "before the drawings were even started," and that he had discussions "concerning what you were going to do up in the penthouse" with Ford Credit prior to the application for the take-out loan commitment. It is remarkable that the testimony, while constituting evidence that there were discussions with Ford Credit about the professional space on the first floor and about what the Limited Partnership was going to do in the penthouse, never established that discussions "concerning the professional space on the first floor" and "what you were going to do up in the penthouse" ever touched on the matter of leaving those two floors incomplete. 2. The perhaps calculated imprecision on that subject in the testimony may well be explained by the fact that it dealt with discussions prior to the execution of the take-out loan commitment on February 14, 1973. The fully integrated documents providing the take-out commitment called for completion of "all buildings and improvements in accordance with plans and specifications therefor," and the plans and specifications did not exempt from the completion requirement the first floor and penthouse. The provisions contradicted what the Limited Partnership now asserts was its intention all along. The doctrine of integration14 probably would have rendered the evidence inadmissible if it had become any more explicit. Just because it was inexplicit, however, it fails to mount up to the necessary quantum of proof to establish that Ford Credit, despite the language to the contrary in the take-out loan commitment, nevertheless, consented to noncompletion of the first floor and penthouse. It is not amiss to point out that no claim for reformation of the commitment document was ever sought by the Limited Partnership. 3. In about July 1975, which is the earliest date for which there is evidence that it was brought to Ford Credit's attention that the Limited Partnership was making no effort to complete the first floor and penthouse by September 1, 1975, Ford Credit immediately and unequivocally replied that it would insist on completion in accordance with the take-out commitment language. We may discount perhaps the importance of testimony as to the behavior of Ford Credit in view of the self-interest of Ford Credit at a time when the market had gravely deteriorated. What is harder, to the point of impossibility, to discount, however, is the response of the Limited Partnership. It did not as one would expect, if there were any substance to the contention that Ford Credit had indeed consented to noncompletion of the first floor and penthouse, write a letter reminding Ford Credit that it had consented. Instead the Limited Partnership simply wrote "We cannot have all units completed prior to settlement. Further, if you demand they be finished I would not know how to comply." Hence, on the record as it has been provided for us, summary judgment apparently should have been granted in favor of Ford Credit. I turn now to my reasons for saying that it appears that the Limited Partnership, by deliberately leaving unfinished the first floor and penthouse, indisputably failed to meet a condition precedent to the take-out commitment and, therefore, should have been found, as a matter of law, not to have been entitled to have Ford Credit make the loan. The Limited Partnership, of which Cornelius M. Whalen was the sole general partner, was organized in May 1972 to develop 24 parcels of land in Towson, Maryland comprising in all approximately 6.66 acres. The particular project engaging our attention was the erection of a high-rise condominium on 1.66 acres. Inspections may be made by Ford Credit, or an independent architect retained by Ford Credit and compensated by Borrower, at any and all times during construction and after completion thereof, and satisfactory certificates of any such independent architect shall be submitted to Ford Credit at least quarterly. ("Builder") the general contractor.16 By Article 2 of that agreement the Builder obliged itself to "perform all the work required by the Contract Documents for TOWSON CENTER APARTMENTS, TOWSON, MARYLAND." (Emphasis added.) Article 4 in its entirety read: ARTICLE 4 TIME OF COMMENCEMENT AND COMPLETION The Work to be performed under this Contract shall be commenced 5 SEPTEMBER 1973 and completed 1 FEBRUARY 1975 (Here insert any special provisions for liquidated damages relating to failure to complete on time.) Article 6 stated: ARTICLE 6 PROGRESS PAYMENTS Based upon Applications for Payment submitted to the Architect by the Contractor and Certificates for Payment issued by the Architect, the Owner shall make progress payments on account of the Contract Sum to the Contractor as provided in the Conditions of the Contract as follows: On or about the 10th day of each month 90 per cent of the proportion of the Contract Sum properly allocable to labor, materials and equipment incorporated in the Work and 90 per cent of the portion of the Contract Sum properly allocable to materials and equipment suitably stored at the site or at some other location agreed upon in writing by the parties, up to the 25th day of that month, less the aggregate of previous payments in each case; and upon Substantial Completion of the entire Work, a sum sufficient to increase the total payments to 100 per cent of the Contract Sum, less such retainages as the Architect shall determine for all incomplete Work and unsettled claims. (Here insert any provisions made for limiting or reducing the amount retained after the Work reaches a certain stage of completion.) Again, no insertions were made. On April 10, 1973, the commitment from Ford Credit to the Limited Partnership had been amended, granting the Limited Partnership the right, upon payment of an additional fee, to extend the expiration date of its option from Ford Credit until September 1, 1975. At that time, Ford Credit explicitly provided that, except for the amendment, "all terms and conditions of the Commitment are unchanged and remain in full force and effect." On January 21, 1975, the Limited Partnership exercised its right to extend. In the period following August 1973 Distasio & VanBuren, a firm of consulting architects chosen by Equibank, the construction lender, and by Ford Credit, also gave its approval to the plans and specifications.
