There was, however, one important exception. The projected condominium building envisaged development of the first floor for professional office purposes and the 27th or penthouse floor for luxury residences. Except for a maximum of 8 units18 which might be dedicated to special office purposes, all units in the Towson Center Apartments were to be used solely as single family residences. The plans and specifications approved by the parties indicated completion of the first floor and penthouse as if they were typical floors. The parties noted on the plans that such completion of the penthouse floor was indicated "for pricing purposes only," but that only meant, of course, that substitution of other plans for completion was contemplated, not that there was complete abrogation of the duty to complete.19 The Limited Partnership unilaterally determined not to complete the first floor and penthouse areas, apparently without seeking or obtaining the consent of Ford Credit. The asserted justification was that it was "standard practice" or a "field understanding" that space designed for professional and penthouse use would remain incomplete until sold and custom-designed by the purchaser. The Limited Partnership in July and August of 1975 stated to Ford Credit that it would not seek to complete the first floor and penthouse pending the working out of architectual design with the tenants and prospective tenants. Ford Credit's response was simply that the Limited Partnership should adhere to the requirements of the take-out commitment. Its representative told Whalen, the general partner of the Limited Partnership, that "I should get them finished; that is all."20 Distasio & VanBuren gave a certificate on August 28, 1975, no more than five days prior to the last date by which all conditions precedent had to be satisfied for the take-out commitment to be enforceable. The certificate stated that "the project is complete, substantially in accordance with the Plans and Specifications..., excepting and excluding certain areas which are subject to tenant improvements." Also on August 28, 1975, Disatasio & VanBuren certified that it would "cost approximately $120,250.00 to complete the tenant improvement areas in accordance with the plans and specifications." The figure of $120,250.00 was exclusive of the cost of carpeting individual apartments, estimated to be $169,000.00. On August 31, 1975, one day prior to the expiration date, Mr. Elliott Gitlin, who had been retained by the Limited Partnership to act as the supervisory architect, certified that the building was "substantially completed with the exception of the penthouse and plaza levels." In an August 29, 1975 certificate Gitlin opined: "The penthouse and plaza level tenant space is not complete." Indeed, the Limited Partnership makes no contention that the first floor and penthouse were complete, stating flatly in its brief, "it was obvious no effort was being made to complete these areas." It is instructive that, with respect to carpeting of each of the units in the project, it was deferred, not completed in accordance with the plans and specifications. The reasons were the same as those advanced for not completing the first floor and penthouse. Deferral would allow choice by the tenant. The Limited Partnership did not, however, in striking contrast to its behavior on noncompletion of the first floor and penthouse, proceed without seeking Equibank's and Ford Credit's agreement, in advance, that the carpeting was not going to be part of the construction loan (in the case of Equibank) or the commitment (in the case of Ford Credit). To the contrary, Cornelius M. Whalen testified that Ford Credit was approached and agreed not to require completion of carpeting "prior even to their commitment." Furthermore, the plans and specifications clearly remove carpeting from the project. See Plaintiff's Exhibit 429, at p. 9.68-1: "All carpeting indicated on drawings in [sic, read 'is'] N.I.C. (Not in Contract)." When September 2, 1975 came, Ford Credit stood by its asserted rights and refused to take out the construction loan on the grounds that the condition precedent to its doing so, "completion," had not occurred. On December 10, 1975, suit was instituted in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland with diversity as the jurisdictional predicate. Trial commenced on March 31, 1980 before Judge C. Stanley Blair and a jury. After an interruption of 18 days, from April 20 until May 8 occasioned by Judge Blair's death, trial resumed on May 8, 1980. The jury verdict in favor of the Limited Partnership in the amount of $3,371,000 was returned on May 22, 1980. Judge Murray calculated the interest at $923,746, making the aggregate of the judgment $4,294,746. Turning to a resolution of the problems posed by those facts, we find ourselves engaged in the ascertainment of meanings ascribed to words by the parties in a rather fluid if not unstable set of circumstances. In committing itself to the owner to be the take-out lender, Ford Credit made it a condition precedent that the building be "completed" by the date originally agreed on of March 1, 1975, subsequently by amendment changed to September 1, 1975. In addressing the meaning assigned by the parties to "completed" we may not properly deal with the matter as an arithmetical exercise. We cannot simply say that a building is "completed" when it is totally and fully finished in every respect and detail, and "incomplete" otherwise. The linguistic simplicity of such an approach has its appeal. However, the world in which we live and in which documents of the type here under consideration are drawn is a real, not merely a linguistic, world. Those engaged in large business undertakings (such as the multi-million dollar enterprise before us) obviously do not contemplate such a construction of "completed." They recognize that a single broken window pane, or light bulbs which do not operate, a final coat of paint that has not been applied, leaks, or perhaps an elevator whose full functioning is still interrupted by mysterious kinks which the experts have not yet succeeded in eliminating21 do not prohibit a description of the building as "complete."22 Language, it must be remembered, is our servant, designed to express what we mean, not a master imposing meanings which we have not intended. At the same time, in transactions such as this, it is important to bear in mind that the take-out lender, back from the very outset before construction has even started,23 has as an objective the avoidance of involvement in the building process. It does not want to make its loan while work is still in progress with all the potential hassles and uncertainties inherent in associations with the building trades. The lender recognizes that in any construction undertaking a point is reached where the matters remaining to put the building in a state of total completion24 are trivial and so little interruptive of the functioning of the project that they may be disregarded, and the building recognized to be "complete." However, recognizing that reality of life, still the permanent lender is entitled to expect and, indeed, genuinely does expect that the owner and builder will strive to the utmost to achieve full completion. That is why the loan commitment requires that construction be "diligently prosecuted to completion." The lender understands that the builder and owner will be excused where they have utilized every reasonable means to bring matters to completion but have been unable in a perfect sense to do so because of matters beyond their control, i.e., the items that fall into the "this is not a perfect world" category. The case on which the Limited Partnership principally relies, St. Paul at Chase Corp. v. Manufacturers Life Ins. Co., 262 Md. 192, 278 A.2d 12 (1971), cert. denied, 404 U.S. 857 (1971), fully illustrates the point. The parties there conditioned the take-out loan on "satisfactory completion." As I have already indicated, the condition of "completion" imposed by Ford Credit is the same as "satisfactory completion," and does not mean 100% completion.25 The crucial distinction between that case and the one presented to us was the finding by the trial court there, adopted by the Maryland Court of Appeals: Now in the first quotation it is stated that 'performance accompanied by good faith is all the law requires', and I don't think that anyone can say that St. Paul and Williams did not operate in good faith. They did everything possible to push for the completion of this project by the 7th of March, 1966. Id., 262 Md. at 229, 278 A.2d at 30. Elsewhere the opinion points out that the items asserted to show a lack of satisfactory completion were principally "nitpicking." Id. 262 Md. at 213, 278 A.2d at 23. Only one item had any substance, namely leaking on the 22nd and 23rd floor. It may have been attributable to a bad blizzard, certainly not of the owner's making. And if not, no single iota of evidence pointed to any indifference or failure to seek to remedy the leak. The court's finding as indicated in the prior paragraph was that every effort to complete was made.26 The deliberate decision of the Limited Partnership not even to try and meet the condition precedent, insofar as the first floor and penthouse were concerned, is vitally important for another reason. The Limited Partnership expectably cries forfeiture because it lost the project when the take-out loan was not forthcoming. E.g. St. Paul at Chase, supra, 262 Md. at 232, 278 A.2d at 31: In determining the answer to this question, it is necessary that the Court bear in mind that basically, the law frowns on forfeitures of any kind. That's what the effect of this cancellation was--all that had been expended on that building at the date of cancellation was lost, so far as St. Paul was concerned. Transactions, as here, are often gigantic in amount. Courts are properly not disposed to sanction forfeiture because of an unforeseen complication or complications--its or their incompleteness trivial, in contrast to the project as a whole and to its advanced state of completion--on the critical take-out commitment date, for difficulties not of the owner's own making. Risk as to such matters is assessed as never having been intended by the parties to fall exclusively on the owner. However, while that may excuse the Limited Partnership for a number of incompletions in the Towson project (arguably all save the first floor and penthouse), it does not for the deliberate, conscious decision not even to try to complete the first floor and penthouse. There incompleteness was distinctly of the owner's own making. A frank concession was made: "It was obvious no effort was being made to complete these areas." Therefore, the condition precedent was not met. By the terms of the agreement between the Limited Partnership and Ford Credit, the latter was, consequently, not obligated to make the take-out loan. The equitable objective of relieving someone from a forfeiture does not extend so far as to protect against a knowing, deliberate failure to comply with an express condition precedent, on compliance with which performance by the other party depends. City Bank of Baltimore v. Smith, 3 Gill & J. 265, 380-81 (Md. 1831): But it has been strongly urged, that the assignees of the mortgage took it subject to all the equity of the mortgagor as against the mortgagee; and that this being the case of a condition, equity will relieve against the effects of the non-performance of it, by giving to the defendant the benefit of the prizes, though not demanded according to the condition. Equity will relieve against penalties and forfeitures, and where the matter lies in compensation, whether the condition be subsequent or precedent; as if it be for the payment of a certain sum of money at a certain day, and the payment at a subsequent day will be a compensation for the non-performance, the intent being to secure the payment of the money. But notwithstanding it will, in many cases, interpose to prevent the divesting an estate, it will not relieve against the non-performance of a condition precedent to the vesting of an estate, by giving an estate that never vested; it will not vest an estate, that by reason of the non-performance of a condition precedent will not vest in law. This is not a case of forfeiture. No right to the prizes for which the credit is claimed, was ever acquired, to be forfeited. In determining whether the condition that I have labelled "functional completion"27 has been met there is apt to be inherent uncertainty in most cases--a matter of disputed fact probably requiring the intervention of a jury when a jury trial has been requested--as to whether matters not in a state of perfection by the crucial date (here September 2, 1975) sufficed to render the building not "functionally complete." It is the most unusual case--yet this appears to be that case--where a party would expose itself to disastrous consequences by consciously leaving altogether undone steps unambiguously required to be diligently prosecuted at least if it was to meet the condition precedent. There may also be cases where, however diligent the owner and builder may have been, however mightily they may have striven, they may simply have been unable to reach a stage which anyone under any definition could describe as "complete." If a whole segment of the building has not been erected at all or has only been roofed in but the floors have not been laid or the pulmbing installed, the building is not "complete." See S & S Building Corp. v. Fidelity Storage Corp., 270 Md. 184, 189, 310 A.2d 778, 781 (1973) ("... to tender a structure as completed when the sprinkler system was deficient would be in about the same category as tendering as complete an office structure or apartment building in which the heating plant had not been installed."). Incompleteness of that glaring and evident type is not, however, present here. What is present, nevertheless, is an undisputed and dispositive fact apparently calling for resolution in favor of one of the parties without the intervention of a jury. As a general rule of interpretation, where the owner or builder has unilaterally taken it upon itself, when operating under an arrangement like the take-out loan commitment from Ford Credit to the Limited Partnership, to decide not to do certain work included in the plans and specifications, that action without the consent of the other party amounts to an incontestable failure to satisfy a condition precedent. If the owner or builder should take it on himself to do so, whatever the reason, and however wise or prudent it may seem to him, absent the consent of the permanent lender the purposeful failure even to attempt to finish a portion of the project inevitably means that functional completion, as understood by the parties from the outset, has not been achieved. In the present case there would seem to be no dispute of fact raising a jury question as to whether a unilateral determination not to finish a portion of the project did in fact occur. The owner indisputably from the record is shown to have taken a decision with respect to which he, for all that appears, did not consult the lender and for which the lender never gave consent nor waived its right to insist on full functional completion.28 The owner, all on its own, elected to leave the penthouse and first floor unfinished, on the hopes that the opportunities thereby afforded prospective purchasers to have a say in the building decor, would enhance successful disposition.29 However "reasonable" that may sound, the permanent lender was not obliged to agree. As is so often the case, "reckoning without mine host" may prove a costly mistake. It appears to have done so here. The owner, the Limited Partnership, adopted the supposed improvement without consulting, much less securing the consent of, Ford Credit. Per its directions, the Builder unquestionably did not accomplish the full functional completion necessary to meet the condition precedent of the take-out loan commitment. Judgment should, therefore, be entered in favor of Ford Credit.30 The Limited Partnership contests that rationale, arguing that the word "substantial" is implicit before "completion" in the contract between it and Ford Credit. It infers that the finishing of the first floor and the penthouse, which would have cost "only" an estimated $120,250, was not substantial. The contention suggests a difficult snarl, which fortunately we are not called upon to untangle. Only the first floor could be used for commercial purposes. The penthouse could only be developed as single family residences, like the other 25 floors.31 If the Limited Partnership was free to leave one floor unfinished, merely "roughedin," to gratify the wishes of prospective occupants, without thereby jeopardizing the availability of the take-out money, why not all the other floors as well?32 The Limited Partnership may be expected to contend that only the penthouse was to be developed in luxury apartments. However, one searches the documents in vain for an indication that as to "completion * *," a different test applied for luxury apartments than for other "normal" apartments. The Limited Partnership, still pursuing the incorrect assumption that substantial completion * * * is the test, then points to evidence which Ford Credit itself agrees would have permitted a finding of "substantial completion * * *" by September 1, 1975. However, to the extent, if any, that "substantial completion * * *" is relevant, it concerns the question whether the owner and builder, assuming they have striven to get everything ready by the crucial date, still have had to leave some things, relatively minor in amount, for future attention and completion * * *, not amounting to enough to interrupt or prevent "functional completion * *." The usage "substantial completion * * *" can, however, have no significance with respect to circumstances where the owner has taken it on itself unilaterally to revise the agreement by excluding parts of the project (here the first floor and penthouse) from the requirement that they make every effort to achieve "completion * *" by the date as of which the condition precedent must be satisfied. So to recapitulate, the parties agreed to "functional completion * *", diligently prosecuted, by September 1, 1975 as a condition precedent to the loan. The condition simply was not met because the owner and builder had not striven to complete * * the first floor and penthouse. Instead, they had flatly determined to leave them incomplete until they had been sold to permit the purchasers to select their own finishings. That may have been wise viewed from some perspectives. However, the fact that it was a good idea from the owner's vantage point did not render it in conformity with the conditions precedent. On the contrary, the lender was entitled under the take-out commitment to full efforts to attempt completion *. The take-out loan terms simply did not allow the owner all on its own to discontinue such efforts with respect to any part of the project absent a consent, in effect an amendment to the commitment, permitting such an alteration. The evidence is unambiguous that no such amendment was sought or given. Perhaps perceiving the problems associated with its decision, all on its own, to leave unfinished the first floor and penthouse, the Limited Partnership argues that it was justified by custom and practice. But that requires the words calling for all the buildings and improvements to be "diligently prosecuted to completion * *" "in accordance with plans and specifications therefor" to be read as meaning the exact opposite, to say "need not be completed * *." Morris v. Ehlers, 211 Md. 23, 29, 124 A.2d 776, 780 (1956): Perhaps the leading case in Maryland on the subject is Applestein v. Royal Realty Corp., 181 Md. 171, 28 A. 2d 830, which succinctly states the rule (at 181 Md. 173, 28 A. 2d 831): "The true test is that there must be in the contract something doubtful which can be explained by a usage or custom. If the contract is plain, evidence cannot be received to contradict it. If the contract is made with reference to a usage and therefore omits the special particulars which are supplied by that usage, those particulars can be supplied by proof of the usage." For a general discussion of the matter, see also Williston, Contracts, Rev. Ed., Vol. 3, Sections 607-609, and Restatement, Contracts, 247. We think that in the present case the testimony as to custom, if given effect, would not explain but would directly contradict a term of the contract and that it therefore cannot be given effect. See also Busby v. North America Life Insurance Co., 40 Md. 572, 579-80 (1874); Foley v. Mason, 6 Md. 37, 49-50 (1854). With commendable determination, if rather little in substance, the Limited Partnership makes a further contention--difficult to understand and even more difficult to accept. It contends that, because a long period of time elapsed after the execution by it and Ford Credit of the take-out commitment without anything being said about the need for completion * * of the first floor and penthouse, it apparently having first come up in correspondence between Ford Credit and the Limited Partnership only in July of 1975, and because Ford Credit's inspectors saw the incomplete state of the first floor and penthouse and said nothing, some sort of waiver or estoppel occurred. However, there is no clear evidence that Ford Credit was even aware that a decision had been taken by the Limited Partnership deliberately not to complete * * the first floor and the penthouse prior to July. When it was brought up, Ford Credit promptly made unequivocally clear its expectation that the terms of the commitment would be met, particularly those calling for completion * *. In all events, the obligation to complete * * the first floor and penthouse was indisputably assigned to the Limited Partnership, not to Ford Credit. It is not a rule of option contract law that, absent any undertaking to do so, one party must monitor performance by another party on whom the undertaking unmistakably has been imposed. Garbis v. Apatoff, 192 Md. 12, 19, 63 A.2d 307, 310 (1949): Plaintiff also contends that, even if his work was not satisfactory, defendants saw its progress and made no objection to it, and their silence should be held as an acceptance of the work and a waiver of any defects. We cannot accept this contention. .... Nor is the failure of an owner to take charge of the prosecution of the work, when he finds that the contractor is not complying strictly with the conditions of the contract, a waiver of his right to damages for defective work. In the instant case there is no basis for the contention that defendants waived any defects in plaintiff's work. The take-out commitment has nowhere any language suggesting that Ford Credit had a responsibility to remind the Limited Partnership of its clearly spelled-out obligation to satisfy the conditions precedent, under penalty of losing the right to insist on compliance with the loan undertaking unless it did so. With fervor, yet altogether lacking in authority to support it, the Limited Partnership has argued that the specification of September 1, 1975 was the establishment of only an approximate date since time was not of the essence. But time was of the essence, since a price had been paid for Ford Credit to hold the take-out commitment open until September 1, 1975. To be required to extend for a reasonable time beyond September 1, 1975 with no provision for an additional fee for the additional time would contradict the very concept of an option to borrow money. See 1 Corbin on Contracts § 35 ("If one pays five hundred dollars for a thirty day option to buy land for twenty thousand dollars, the power to accept for thirty days is the exact agreed equivalent of five hundred dollars. An extension of the power, even for a moment of time, by action of a court, is compelling the offeror to give something for nothing."). The Limited Partnership has argued that the motivation of Ford Credit was attributable not to dissatisfaction with the incomplete state of the first floor and penthouse, but rather to disenchantment with the loan in a changed and unhappy building market. But the argument totally misses the point. The district court quite properly determined that motivation was not an issue, the sole question being whether or not the project was "completed * *" on September 1, 1975 as the parties contemplated. In this the district judge was clearly correct. See Owens v. Graetzel, 149 Md. 689, 697, 132 A. 265, 268 (1926): If the appellant was in default, the appellee had the right to foreclose expressly and plainly given him by the terms of his mortgage. In the assertion of this contractual right, his motive was immaterial, although it were sinister and malicious, because a sinister and malicious motive does not make an act wrongful so long as the act is within the party's legal rights. Cf. Jersey Boulevard Corp. v. Lerner Stores Corp., 168 Md. 532, 540, 178 A. 707, 710 (1935) ("This would be true though evasion of the future obligation to the landlord furnished the principal motive for the bankruptcy; that specific purpose would not affect the exercise of the clear legal right."); Knickerbocker Ice Co. v. Gardiner Dairy Co., 107 Md. 556, 567, 69 A. 405, 409 (1908).33 The efforts to criticize Ford Credit for being dissatisfied with having to go through with the project and for seeking ways not to do so if legally it was not under a contractual obligation are unrealistic. There is nothing to demonstrate that, had the owner endeavored to the end fully to complete * * Ford Credit would not, however unappetizing the project might have become, have gone through with it, complying with its contractual obligations.34 The Limited Partnership gave Ford Credit a legitimate opportunity to say that the loan would not be made because a condition precedent clearly had not been met. The Limited Partnership having been the first to break the agreement, or, more precisely, the one who deliberately elected not to comply with a condition precedent, is not in a position, therefore, to complain that, although it had not done what it was obliged to do, it should nevertheless have been entitled to the loan, however unpalatable it had become. Market conditions inevitably change from time to time. No doubt there was a period in American business affairs when the loan from the lender's point of view would still have been so favorable that, confronted with a situation in which a condition precedent had not been met, the lender might, nevertheless, have chosen to waive the noncompletion and go ahead with the project. Because other lenders had done so in other cases, or even because Ford Credit itself had chosen to do so, in another case or in other cases, did not mean that there was no condition precedent. Rather, it meant only that the lender had, in other situations, elected not to enforce the condition precedent. That in no way prevented the prospective lender, when the business climate had altered, from choosing to rely on the failure to comply with the condition precedent and not go through with the loan. It was fully within the power of the Limited Partnership to strive to complete * * the building. It did not do so. It failed therefore to satisfy the condition precedent. We have no occasion to consider whether, had a bona fide full effort to complete * * been made, the degree of incompletion existing in the case of this particular project would or would not have been sufficient to make the description of "functionally complete * *" appropriate or inappropriate. That may, assuming full efforts had been made to complete * * the first floor and penthouse, as well as the remainder of the building, well have been a jury question. However, the knowing intentional determination not to try to complete * * foreclosed the Limited Partnership and should require the entry of judgment as a matter of law in favor of Ford Credit. III. Finally, I perceive great difficulties in the affirmance of Judge Blair's ruling, which, though without opinion, was in effect a summary judgment, holding as a matter of law that the Limited Partnership retained an interest entitling it to sue, despite an assignment of its interests absolute on its face. The Limited Partnership produced such evidence, but it was controverted by Ford Credit. There was, consequently, a straightforward jury question, and the majority erred in upholding the arrogation by the judge to himself of a decision properly lying in the province of the jury. In one case, irrespective of motive, Ford Credit was bound to make the loan if completion * * was achieved, and not so bound if it was not. All the good faith in the world on the part of Ford Credit would not have excused a failure to produce the loan funds, when demanded by the Limited Partnership, if the building had been completed * * by September 2, 1975. In the other case, the undertaking of the Limited Partnership required it to use good faith efforts to achieve completion *, if it were to satisfy the condition precedent of completion * *. The record is clear that no such efforts were made by the Limited Partnership on the first floor and in the penthouse. Similarly, in another market climate, where money was readily available from a number of sources, for the kind of loan the Limited Partnership wanted, the Limited Partnership, in the most malicious way, could legally have taken its loan business elsewhere, although the spiting of Ford Credit was a major motivation.The reason: because it would be acting within its legal rights in doing so. 34. The fact that the loan had become unpalatable was not Ford Credit's doing.It did not control the market forces; if it did, they doubtless would have remained favorable. Nor is it realistic to expect that the gimlet eyes of a hardheaded lender would overlook that the loan had become, in the interval between February 14, 1973 and September 1, 1975, unappetizing. That also was a fact, not a contrivance by a lender, however mean-minded and hard-hearted it may have been. The Limited Partnership never permitted the situation to develop to a point where Ford Credit might have elected a cold-blooded breach of contract. Before that stage was ever reached, the Limited Partnership relieved Ford Credit of any obligation to make the take-out loan by deciding, all on its own, not to complete * *, not even to prosecute diligently to completion *, part of the project. It simply expects too much from human nature to insist that Ford Credit, provided a perfectly legal escape from a now unprepossessing contract, should refrain from using it, or that Ford Credit behaved badly in not refraining. It was the Limited Partnership, not Ford Credit, which brought the unhappy consequences on the Limited Partnership.
